title: Diploma in Decision Making Using Financial Accounting
headline: Learn to interpret and analyze financial statements and records to support your decision making in this diploma course
description: Diploma in Decision Making Using Financial Accounting is a free online course that offers a comprehensive guide to the different types of financial statements and their importance for effective decision-making. Learn about major accounting principles, types of financial statements, and their application in decision-making for individuals and corporate entities. This course will improve your analytical and decision-making skills.

courseDescription:
This free online accounting for decision makers course provides a comprehensive guide to interpreting and applying financial information in the process of effective decision-making. This course will teach you the fundamental aspects of financial accounting and the process of building and analyzing financial statements. The course begins with a discussion of basic financial accounting concepts, major sources of capital, and how to prepare a balance sheet.

Next, you will learn about the effects of various financial transactions on the financial statements of an organization such as purchases, sales, and miscellaneous items of expenditure. You will also study the fundamental accounting principles and different types of financial records. Then, you will analyze the methods of preparing the cash flow statements and the major components of the cash flow statement. You will also discuss the treasury management function and financial assets and liabilities in analyzing financial statements. Finally, the course will conclude with a discussion on ratio analysis including different types of ratios used in analyzing financial statements.

This free online course will introduce you to the fundamentals of financial accounting and its function in decision-making for individuals and organizations. This course will be of immense interest to students, analysts, investors, and anyone with an interest in interpreting and applying information from financial statements.

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this diploma course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this diploma course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison diploma is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital diploma: a downloadable diploma in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • diploma: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked diploma, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed diploma: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked diploma in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.
Start Course Now

All diploma are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison diploma, please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison diploma, you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our diploma pricing, please visit our Pricing Page

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will learn about concepts that are fundamental to financial accounting and preparing financial statements. Learn about sources of capital, interactions between financial statements, and accounting principles.
topics: Introduction to Financial Accounting Concepts - Learning Outcomes
Introduction to Financial Accounting Concepts - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will learn about the double-entry system of financial accounting and the importance of recording transactions in financial statements. You will also learn about the numerous effects of financial transactions.
topics: Transactions and Financial Statements - Learning Outcomes
Transactions and Financial Statements - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will learn about the importance of keeping a journal and how to analyze various financial transactions. You will also discuss the consolidation of accounts in the ledger and how to prepare the final accounts.
topics: Types of Financial Records - Learning Outcomes
Types of Financial Records - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Diploma in Decision Making Using Financial Accounting - First Assessment
modules.description: You must score 80% or more to pass this assessment.

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to Cash Flow Statements and the need for a cash flow statement. You will also be introduced to the preparation and dissection of cash flow statement, the essence of marketable securities as well as how to trace money generated from net investing and financing.
topics: The Cash Flow Statement - Learning Outcomes
Financing Activities and Closing the Statement
The Cash Flow Statement -  Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will learn about the importance of annual reports to stakeholders in measuring the financial health of a company. You will also learn about analyzing the components of financial statements.
topics: Analyzing the Financial Statements  - Learning Outcomes
Analyzing the Financial Statements - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will learn about the concept of return on equity, as well as the various calculation of profits using profitability ratios. You will also learn about the analysis of a company's performance using ratio and the two types of liquidity ratios.
topics: Ratio Analysis and Working Capital Requirements

slides:
• Learning Outcomes
  • Upon successful completion of this module, you should be able to: 
    • Recognize the fundamental concepts of financial accounting
    • Identify the types of financial statements 
    • Distinguish between profit and loss, and revenue and expenditure
    • Describe the relationship between assets and liabilities
    • Discuss the advantages and limitations of the accounting system
    • Analyze the features of the major sources of capital
    • Explain the double-entry system of accounting
  • Introduction to Basic Accounting Concepts

  • Lesson Summary
    • Maintaining proper financial records is important for better decision-making in every organization
    • There are three major financial statements of every organization - the profit or loss statement, the balance sheet, and the statement of cash flows. The preparation of financial statements are guided by various accounting principles and concepts
    • Depreciation is the reduction in the value of an asset due to usage and passage of time and it cannot be avoided. Depreciation, as an accounting method, is the allocation of the cost of a tangible or physical asset over its useful life or life expectancy
    • The accrual basis of accounting holds that revenue or expenses are recorded when a transaction occurs rather than when payment is received or made
    • In the preparation of your financial statement, you need to have an income and expenditure statement as a guide to create your balance sheet
    • The major sources of funds for a company are categorized into equity, preference shares, and debt capital. There are different types of debentures - secured, unsecured, convertible, and non-convertible
    • Risk return shows the difference between a high and low risk where a high risk brings high returns
    • Shares can be issued through Initial Public Offering (IPO) and seasoned offering
  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Discuss the types of financial statements
    • Explain the double-entry system of financial accounting
    • Outline the three forms a partner can draw money from an organization
    • Categorize investment equity into short-term and long-term
    • Explain the effects of depreciation
    • Describe what a tax rebate stands for
    • Evaluate the importance of recording financial transactions for businesses

  • Lesson Summary
    • The main principle of the double-entry system is that for every debit there is a corresponding credit and for every credit, there is a corresponding debit, for an equal amount of money. Therefore, every transaction must be recorded in a minimum of two accounts
    • Sales return is when a product that has been sold is returned by the customer which will lead to a decrease in sales and cash. Purchase return is when you buy goods and return them to your supplier which will lead to a decrease in purchase but an increase in cash
    • There are different methods of depreciating assets. The most common methods are the straight-line method and the reducing balance method
    • A discount is a reduction in the original price of a product based on certain conditions. It could be a cash discount or a trade discount
    • A business partner can withdraw money from an organization through several means such as salary, loans, and dividend distributed as profit
    • Authorized share capital is the number of shares a company can issue as stated in its memorandum of association or its articles of incorporation
    • Export transactions have foreign exchange risk which is the threat of financial loss when foreign exchange rates change
    • The balance sheet statement is made up of two sides - assets, and equity and liabilities. Both sides of a balance sheet must balance
  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Recognize the importance of keeping an accounting journal
    • Identify key accounting principles that guide recording transactions
    • Outline the broad categories of transactions and accounts
    • Discuss the various types of financial statements
    • Explain the consolidation of accounts in the ledger
    • Evaluate the effects of different types of financial transactions
    • Analyze the process of preparing the final accounts

  • Setting up the Final Ledger

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Setting up the Final Ledger

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Setting up the Final Ledger

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary
    • A journal entry is a record of the business transactions in the accounting books of an organization. It is the first step in the accounting cycle
    • Every transaction has two journal entries: a debit and a credit. Debits must always equal credits
    • Debit and credit accounts and update the records to reflect transactions and their effects on financial records. Debit all expenses and losses, and credit all income and gains
    • The ledger is prepared by consolidating all the journal entries for a given period into the ledger accounts
    • The ledger accounts are used to prepare the trial balance which in turn is used to prepare the financial statements
    • Ledger is a book containing accounts in which summarized information from the journals is posted as debits and credits. It is the principal book of accounts and it forms a permanent record of all business transactions
    • The final accounts are prepared at the end of a fiscal year and they include the profit or loss statement and the balance sheet. They determine the profitability of a business and show the financial position
